Award.AwardTitle: Periodic Phenomena and the Evolution of Cataclysmic Variable Binary Stars
Award.AbstractNarration:
1. Most stars occur in systems containing two or more objects. Some pairs include a very dense star called a ?white dwarf? ? a star with the mass of our Sun crammed into a volume about the size of the Earth ? plus an ordinary star smaller and redder than the Sun. In some cases, the red star can transfer a stream of mass onto a disk of gas around the white dwarf. Matter spirals in through the disk to accumulate on the white dwarf, heating up rapidly and shining brightly for a time. The resulting outburst of energy gives these so-called ?cataclysmic variables? (CVs) their name. Monitoring CVs for outbursts, or to study the wealth of periodic signals they display, requires far more telescope time than professional astronomers can afford. For the past two decades, the Principal Investigator has been leading a world-wide group of amateur astronomers using small telescopes ? which he calls the ?Center for Backyard Astrophysics? ? to obtain the necessary observations of CVs. The data have proven extremely useful to professional astronomers who study these systems. This project continues that fruitful collaboration, engaging amateurs around the world in valuable ?citizen science.?

2. Most of the information about CVs comes from various periodic signals they exhibit. Yet few professional observers have been willing to devote the time necessary to monitor these systems in order to measure period changes (which can reveal their evolutionary timescales) or to obtain data on additional periodic phenomena they may display. These include orbital periods and period changes, rotational periods, and so-called ?superhumps? in certain classes of CVs. This proposal seeks to obtain long-term time-series photometry from a world-wide network of amateur astronomers using small telescopes ? called the ?Center for Backyard Astrophysics? or CBA ? to fill this need. In addition, the Principal Investigator expects to be able to use the data obtained to help distinguish between two diametrically opposed theories for the fate of CV systems: Are the donor stars whittled away by mass transfer to the white dwarf primary, or are they evaporated by nova explosions on the white dwarfs? The photometric time-series data and their implications for improving our understanding of CVs constitute the Intellectual Merit of this project. The Broader Impacts of this project stem from the Principal Investigator?s continuing ability to motivate and engage the world-wide community of amateur astronomers to gather scientifically useful photometric data on these systems. The amateur observers willingly and continually fill the gap in observational data that has been largely abandoned by the professionals, and under the leadership of the Principal Investigator they produce a steady stream of valuable photometric data on a wide variety of CVs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
.
   Cataclysmic variables are double stars known for their erratic and 
explosive behavior (novae, dwarf novae).  Much of our knowledge of these 
stars comes from the telescopic observations of amateur astronomers 
scattered around the world.  Many of taday's "amateurs" have 
equipment which can measure the brightness of stars as accurately as 
professional telescopes; and because they are worldwide, they do not 
encounter some of the problems of professional telescopes (weather, 
restriction to one latitude/longitude).   

The Center for Backyard Astrophyics (CBA), headquartered at 
Columbia University, organizes telescopic campaigns among the 
world's amateurs.  These campaigns are designed to reveal the fine 
details of the stars' structure, and especially their periodic signals - 
resulting from the orbit, rotation, precession, and pulsation.  For all 
but the last of these, we're the world's leaders.   Most of our observers 
operate their telescopes under computer control, and therefore can run
 all night... and enable the humans to have day jobs.  Thanks to NSF 
suppport and 20 years of work, we now have a telescope network 
ranging north-south from Finland to New Zealand, and east-west 
on every inhabited continent.  Thus we can, in principle, follow stars 
for 24 hours a day, many weeks on end.  This broad distribution is 
what allows our detection limits to be so sensitive.  We declare 
“campaigns” on ~40  stars per year; for each star, we average ~12-18 
hours/night over a typical 2-nonth observing season.  Of course, there 
are hundreds of stars to track, so we do not reach this Olympian level 
for all of them.    
     All CBA citizen-scientists started with their own telescopes and 
data acquisition software.  Through our news-rooms and chat-rooms 
(cbastro.org), we discuss new products (telescopes, detectors, 
software) … and in a few cases send equipment to under-represented 
latitudes and longitudes (South Africa, Uzbekistan, Finland).  In this 
manner, the network gets steadily more powerful.  The observers' data 
is pipelined to Columbia, and archived at the AAVSO, where it is 
available for analysis by the world's community of astronomers.  This 
enables the much larger professional community to make full use of 
the data, which is ideally organized for science purposes (because 
it's in the form of “campaigns”). 
    During the report period (2017-20), we published 17 papers, with 
11 in the refereed journals.  All contributing observers (nearly all 
“amateur” astronomers) are included as co-authors.  We discovered 
large-amplitude superhumps in the X-ray binary MAXI J1820+-70, 
long-term orbital period changes in many cataclysmic variables, and 
short-term spin-period  changes in 6 magnetic stars.  Most 
mysteriously, we found that one star (T Pyx, the most famous 
“recurrent nova” in the sky) is blowing itself apart on a timescale of a 
mere million years.  This has moved us to organize similar campaigns 
on every bright nova we find in future years.
